reviewText: Here is a product that I've been playing around with for a few days and decided to make a small video. These are gaming lights from ambx that teamed up with Madcatz's Cyborg PC gaming division to create a 2 point lighting system for games, movies and music. I really love this set, though it's a 2 point lighting system, it would have been nice to have 3 lights. (left, right and center) The program is simple to use and works with every game, music player and movie player. This only works for PC and not for consoles. You can add more lights with a total of 9 lights and if you so want 3 lights per sector, total of 27 LIGHTS! Crazy! Not only does it work for games but you can also set it actions like getting a new email or instant message (setting a color for it) be in sync with you screen saver and setting a static color background. Nothing I can see bad or frustrating about this product other than the price, should have been at least 3 lights for $100
good game

First, I want to talk.about how user friendly this is. Typing isn't too loud, in a dark room you can change from Purple (bright) or Blue (bright) to Red (dark but still lit) to kill the glare. The ONLY downside to the mouse is I have no idea hoe.to keep it one color. Granted, it's a cool feature to see it change colors all the time, the design is FLAWLESS. But on nights like last night, where I just wanted a dark setting, the mouse was just glaring into the corner of my eye while playing an MMO. The wheel on the mouse is smooth, the mousepad feels incredible, clicking is solid and so far I have had no pain in my hand from extended use.

We got this for my nieces and nephews for Christmas. I'm a real gamer, my wife plays a few games now and then. Neither of us has played any of the other I spy games. We've seen the books, but I haven't found this type of thing interesting since I was little and where's waldo was popular.

We always try out games before we give them to the kids, and usually we play them for 10 or fifteen minutes. I played this for a few hours, and now my wife's addicted too! We're sure the kids are going to love it too! You just zoom around and find whatever is in the riddle. Some of it's hard to find, but us adults have always found everything.

So you have to move around a 3-d level and find the items in a riddle. There are about 10 items per riddle and in all there are 40 riddles. The movements you can make are limited (your movements are on "rails"). This is actually a good thing since it it's impossible to get lost.

It's not given a 5 because it's a "perfect game", but because it does enough right to get played a lot in my house. I got it cheap because of a special deal. I don't think it's a must buy at $30, but it's definitely a great buy when it becomes a budget game.

I don't know how long it will be for sure yet, but I'm guessing that it will take us adults somewhere in the 8-10 hour range to finish it (40 riddles with 10 to 15 minutes each). I think it will take the kids longer.

Cons:
1. Sometimes the controls are a little wonky. Never had more than a momentary problem, so it's not a game killer. Also, sometimes you need to hit the number 2. Why games that control mainly with the arrow keys, a & b make you also hit the 2 button is beyond me.
2. This isn't a con if you play with your kids. Some things may need adult help--especially for kids who can't read. One of the clues is a "rebus 4 U". You're supposed to find the letter U, but they should have just put "find the letter 'U'". Clues that hard are rare. The game requires reading in some puzzles where you have to find words. Etc. Reading ones are common.
3. The gameplay is repetitive, but it's 'I spy'. What do you expect? But, I didn't like how some of the mini-games where repetitive. Kids may enjoy that repetition. There also are only 10 levels that you visit a number of times (there are 40 puzzles, so I assume you'll visit each level 4 times).

Pros:
1. Non violent puzzle fun that everyone can help with. Even though only one player controls the wiimote, my wife and I have so far sat at the tv and pointed things out to each other.
2. Good 3d graphics. Nothing amazing, but if it were just a 2d where's waldo on the wii, we wouldn't like it near as much!
3. The actual pointing at items and moving around the level is very accurate. You can use the arrow keys to move around, but the nunchuk works great too!
4. There are a few nice additions. There is a final goal in building this machine. You can play the mini-games with a second player (not interesting to us adults).
5. Auto saving. It's 2008, why doesn't every game autosave?

edited out a half sentence on 07-23-09. We still love the game!
summary: A lot of non-violent fun for the whole family!

reviewText: This game is a very popular game with many including me.  I seem to have lost interest since there have been other games that have caught my interest.  The blood and violence is just something that can't be fun forever.  Sometimes you just have to stray away from something like this so it does not become a dust collector like mine.

I would like to say the game has excellent graphics and great audio. I was impressed in the beginning of the game. The combat and gameplay was good, but after an hour or so the gameplay was becoming tedious (boring).

I realized you have to do the same objectives (with different bosses)over and over again. Don't get me wrong, the bosses were epic but to get through one circle (stage) to the other circle and to defeat the bosses was very repetitive. Furthermore, I felt the story was lacking substance, because it talks about his seven sins with a brief cinematic scene...that's all. Also, the way you collect a Judas coin, a relic or any other other object you do it in the same fashion: pull out your cross and hit circle several times.

Having said that, I would recommend to get God of War 3, because the developers are known to add originality and better story lines for the God of War franchise--we all know that God of War III will be on a massive scale.
summary: SAVE YOUR MONEY FOR GOD OF WAR 3

reviewText:
Well, Deception probably has the greatest opening sequence that I've ever seen in any game, whether it be fighting game, racing or RPG, and the endings are really awesome.  Other than that, the core gameplay hasn't changed much from Deadly Alliance aside from combo breakers, and that's not such a good thing in my mind.  Although the likeness of the Chess and Puzzle Kombat mini games (Super Puzzle Fighter II Turbo, but with MK characters and Stage fatalities), and the increasingly boring and freaquently dry Konquest mode make a mountain out of the replay value, the core gameplay is just as hard to get used to as in the last game.

  I miss what MK 4 used to be, which was in my opinion the best of the series, which basically proves what most gamers (hopefully) believe, it's the gameplay not the graphics.  The one thing I could do without is the Krypt, which is annoying and tedious, and requires you to actually go through the ever dragging Konquest mode mentioned above. It basically takes you from the beginning of Mortal Kombat to the current story of Deception as Shujinko, and gives you a better understanding of how Onaga, the Dragon King (Cheep Boss) resurrected and tricked the nutty old narrator (Shujinko) of the opening sequence (breathtaking), all just to collect stupid "Krypt keys" that unlock stages and characters, which by the way are awesome and make the nostalgia factor go through the roof.  All in all, the obligation of Konquest mode makes unlocking the characters seem more like a dragging job than a fun and rewarding experience.

  The core gameplay isn't what it's cracked up to be, as said earlier, not much was changed from Deadly Alliance. If you loved Deadly Alliance, though, you're in luck.  They did add one more fatality per character, making 2 for each, and probably the coolest addition to Mortal Kombat, Hara-Kiri's. That is basically a chance for you to kill yourself at the end of a lost match before your opponent does a fatality on you, making it sort-of a race to see who can do a fatality first, and still giving you a chance to control your character after you've lost.  Classic stages like the Pit 1, the Dead Pool and the Living Forest make a return and are looking prettier than ever. The return of Ermak, Nightwolf, Baraka, Milleena, Sindel and Noob-Smoke, the tag-team version of Noob-Siabot and Smoke.  Each of them seemlessly change out like switching fighting styles, but they have no weapon.  Those classic characters are definetly something to look forward to!

  The graphics are the best in the series and some of the best I've seen the PS2 put out, and immensly impressive when juxtaposed to the august visuals of Tekken 5 and VF4 Evolution.  The characters have an almost un-precedented amount of detail, and the stages are vast and, surprisingly vibrant considering the dark moodiness that MK games have delivered since MK2, but that's not a bad thing, especially since it shows off how awesome the game looks. The sound, however, is definetly this games knight in shining armor, but as long as they don't get rid of Dan "Toasty" Forden, nobody has anything to worry about.

  The Premium Packs for (Sub-Zero for PS2 and Mileena, Baraka, Scorpion and Raiden for XBOX), includes a serialized metal trading card of the character on the cover and an extra disk with some behind-the-scenes-esque footage of most of the characters and an arcade-perfect port of The One that started it all, baby! Other fighting games take note.

  Mortal Kombat Deception is great and delivers the bloody Kombat that people have come to expect and love, although it's just in need of an overhaul gameplay-wise, it's still well-deserving of all the hype it has recieved and fans should definetly not have to think twice before making a purchace!
Awesome game, reminds an classic gamer of the greatest shooter ever DOOM except with over the top graphics and gore effects.  Awesome set, great game, what more do you need.

It's decent for the price, It's very comfortable and nicely built. It has decent sound quality and a touch of sound cancelling...just a touch. Sadly, sounds does leak the higher the volume is. I went through two different pairs of Turtlebeach Z11's that had sound leaking so I'm used to it but it's not favorable.

Unlike the sound quality being decent the mic on the other hand is kinda awful. At first it's like your mic can't be picked up. You have to raise the volume and boost level, every single time you enable it. The worst part is that there is static in the background of the mic. It sounds like a fan in the distance. It doesn't matter if you have one on or not, you will hear this static regardless and raising the volume and boost only hightens it. I would not recommend the mic for recording. Honestly, I wouldn't even recommend it for Skype as the static could annoy some people. I'd only recommend it for communicating in games, especially games like MGS V that don't have a push-to-talk button. It's good for communicating and being able to mute yourself since it has a mute button but nothing more.
summary: Good sound quality. Bad mic quality.

Dig it mostly, but some config software that isn't quite on the money. Facts are it is a good keyboard with really nice build quality. The software however at this point is not that functional IF you want all its features so it sadly may be a deal breaker for some. The video is just to give you a bit more of a feel for the product that product pictures cant. The backlighting is a bit brighter than show in darker environments I filmed most of that in the afternoon and dusk. I did the mouse and keyboard together since I have a life outside of Amazon reviews and figured I could kill two birds with a lone stone. I really only need the ability to remap buttons to specific colors and I can get it to do that fine. The config needed to update the keyboard at least for that takes fine and works as it should so for me the keyboard does all it has to do in terms of backlighting. In some of the other modes they simply do not work and upload correctly. The splash mode for instance only allows red backlighting as a starting color despite giving the option for other colors. This is a bit of a downer as I am not a fan of rainbow modes but I found this one to be pretty cool if I could have set the starting color to something other than red. Likewise the volume dial (very cool btw!) and function keys are hard wired red which is a bit abrasive if your going for a cooler tone profile, but less of an issue if you run the full color gamut like me. OK with that out of the way we do have a keyboard with plenty of potential and in fact it is very good. Cherry brown switches and an nice metal / plastic build that is a major step up from gaming keyboards of lesser ilk. Hand rest is nice and it will even act as a sound card if you swing that way though I didn't test it. I had no issue with usb mouse pass through but I only tried it on a Ripjaws mouse and a ergonomic mouse that I just got. Both worked without issue and I was able to game (Old star wars games mostly for me with KB mouse) and type / use the net without an issue. Im not a frequent gamer due to hand issue but I do like using the KB and mouse for older FPS games and use a gamepad for most recent games. Keys are a personal preference I don't like typing on mechanical keys for the most part but plenty do without issue. These either come in red or brown cherries and keyboard aficionados will be able to tell the difference but its a bit more subtle if you don't have a specific preference especially between reds / browns (blues are far more obvious). Hopefully the video gives you a decent idea of the click it makes and keep in mind this is the 'brown' variant. Its a really nice and stylish keyboard. Software isn't quite there balance that up and see if your in for that as it has been out for a while and there still seems to be a few gremlins. How one could excuse that aspect entirely is beyond me hence why I am ducking it a star and feel if its important to you then you will likely duck it another. As a personal choice the ability to program a custom key color is all I need and that works fine. I have no friends, so no need to impress anyone with the other modes etc. YMMV. Product provided for review - its just my opinion.
My son needed this for his Xbox. It was a great buy.  It was in good condition.  He is able to use it with his Xbox.  He is very pleased to have it.

The Madden and NCAA Football series have both been criticized for their lack of innovation upon release of the next iteration of the game for years now; NCAA Football 11 did some to change that perception, but NCAA Football 12 kept the same outward appearance, although it did change some gameplay features on the inside. In place of another major overhaul, however, NCAA 13 opted for some new features and animations, making the game more immersive than ever, but doing little to change the game's usual formula.

The new feature this year is Heisman challenge, a glorified Road to Glory mode that allows the player to step in to the shoes of a former Heisman Trophy winner such as Desmond Howard, Barry Sanders, or Charlie Ward, and compete in seasons on any team you wish. Inevitably this will lead to some disgusting combinations, such as Archie Griffin on Michigan or Carson Palmer on Notre Dame, but dwelling on that will only make matters worse. The Heisman Challenge's staple is reaction time, or bullet time, slowing down the game so the player can make cuts or throws with their head instead of quick reactions. In some cases, this is extremely helpful, but it also makes gameplay a little too easy at some levels. Heisman Challenge is definitely something to check out, but it won't keep you entertained for too long.

Dynasty has also seen some under the hood improvements. New recruiting options and features make each game in the season more important, as an underdog win over a top 25 opponent will net you some well-earned popularity with the recruits. This is a very welcome addition, and something which many have been wishing was part of the game for a while. More recruiting options are available for the player as well; Scouting is now an essential part of recruiting. You can see a player's ratings through the season, and target recruits based on your findings instead of being given a base grade. Calling recruits also leads to new gameplay options, and can help swing a recruit towards your school, if you're good enough. In game studio updates, provided by Rece Davis, improve the game's ESPN atmosphere, making it feel even more like you're watching the big game on television; the ESPN ticker gives you the scores from around the nation, and priority score alerts make it even easier to follow the big upsets of the heavy hitting game between top 5 teams.

Road to Glory saw some minor attention this year adding in new challenges as a college player. Despite the lack of a major overhaul it is still as fun as ever; leading your own high school player to the starting spot on a college team is extremely exciting. RTG may even be a little more difficult this year if you choose. It also touts the new reaction time used in the Heisman challenge, and contains better goals to pursue than past iterations, creating a more challenging game.

EA is touting the new animations that have been added to the game, with new receiving and throwing animations being brought into the game to improve realism, and motion blur being added as well. The new animations make the game more lifelike to be sure, and make the players look and feel more athletic, instead of moving about the field in a fashion similar to robots attempting to play American football. Motion blur never seems to be an integral part of the game, however, only popping up on replays and in between plays. Fans do have motion blur, but that seems less important than introducing motion blur in gameplay, and seeing a fan pump their fist with motion blur never made me gaze in wonder at the feat that EA achieved.  Defenses are not the omnipotent beasts they once were, and neither are receivers, for that matter. You need to make sure a receiver is looking for the ball before you throw to them, made easier by the grayed out icons that indicate your receiver is entirely oblivious to the fact you are attempting to throw them the ball. However, defensive players that aren't looking can't block the pass either, a problem that reoccurred throughout NCAA 12.

The biggest lacking feature for this year's NCAA football was the Infinity engine offered by Madden 13. Now, Madden 13 has not come out yet, and thus there has been no clear reference for its engine, giving us no clue whether it is another useless "innovation" provided by Madden or if it's actually a fantastic addition for the game, but it certainly is disappointing that it was not included in this year's NCAA. This is especially disappointing given that, at least in recent years, NCAA had surpassed Madden in being the elite football title produced by EA in terms of gameplay and reception.

The previous iteration of NCAA Football didn't do too much to separate itself from the line of other NCAA's, at least not in a manner similar to NCAA 11, and NCAA 13 doesn't do too much either.  For fans of college football and folks who have picked up each and every other game before it, it's a good buy, but for those simply looking for a recommendation to upgrade from NCAA 12, there's not much reason to spend the extra money for a the Heisman Challenge, new animations, and a roster update. As an individual who spent hundreds of hours on NCAA 12, I picked it up and loved it.

EDIT: I have recently had a lot of trouble loading my dynasty, as it constantly freezes during the game loading screen. I haven't been able to touch my dynasty mode after this, and it's extremely frustrating. Hopefully it will be patched soon, but as of now, with dynasty mode unable to be played correctly, I switch my position to don't buy. Wait until it's patched to buy or just save the money and continue to play '12.
summary: New Heisman Challenge Does Little to Change a Familiar, But Still Fun, Game

reviewText: Great game for my 9 year old son. He loves it

I'm a huge fan of WWII shooters, and if you are too, you should buy this game without reservation.  It's loads of fun, and you play different battles for a change.  I'll list some good and bad below.

Bad Stuff:

1) Short: As other reviews have noted, I was surprised by the short game time.  I wasn't paying attention, but I beat in two days (let's say 10 hours of play, tops).  After finishing the epic Half Life 2 lately, this was pretty bad.

2) Not much of a sequel: This game seems to follow the Halo 2 system of sequels.  Much as Halo 2 really was just a short, over hyped attempt at a massive Halo online game (and just a short, cheap rehashing of the first Halo for the single player), COD2 feels the same.  The multiplayer is a BLAST, but it feels like that was the real design here instead of the single player stuff.

Middle Ground Stuff:

1) Graphics: The graphics aren't bad, but they didn't blow me away. I liked the look of it, but again, recent efforts are a leap ahead of this graphically.  The smoke effects are AWESOME and very helpful for game play, so the game isn't without innovation, but they lacked the crisp texture of Half Life 2 (not to be a fanboy).

2) Linear Game Play: Some reviewers are complaining about linear game play.  Well, guess what, it's a shooter with a story line, so I didn't expect anything different.  You have to follow certain cues.  The levels are rather large with a short load time, and if they were more expansive or the story harder to follow, the game play would suffer.  The action is great, and the objectives are always crystal clear, so no complaints about the linear game play.  I hate shooters where I'm wandering around wondering what to do next, and this never happened here.  I always knew where to go, and if linear game play is the price I pay, it's a welcome price.  This genre doesn't lean to open ended game play, so I think this like complaining there's not enough violence in a romantic comedy.

3) AI: The AI is mixed.  At times, you get pre-generated Nazis perched out waiting to ambush you, but sometimes if you charge a building, the flank you and pull off some nasty surprises.  If you charge the same building on a re-play, you'll not they use totally different tactics.  Even throwing grenades isn't a sure thing since sometimes they throw back.  You get a mix of good and bad AI here pending on the level and circumstance.

Good Stuff:

1) Health System: COD2 avoids the unrealistic magical health packs that heal you and put you back in the fray perfectly healthy (where's the realism there?!).  Instead, you can suffer a certain amount of damage right away and still live.  If it's too much damage all at once, you die (a grenade, a torso or head shot, etc).  However, if it's a small wound, your vision gets screwy, and your aim gets worse, and you recoup in a few seconds if you can take cover.  Repeated hits, though, and you die on the spot.  It enhances the crouch, lay, stand system by making cover make a real difference.  It feels rather like a Halo "force field" system, and it works well.  Instead of watching a health bar and scrounging for band aids, you use your head and stay frosty, and you'll survive a firefight.  The health system makes you think instead of waste time doubling back for that health pack you left at the Nazi desk three building back.  Well done, great game play.

2) New Battles: While staples such as Stalingrad and D-Day are there, you play a different part of those battles.  You do a lot of the African campaign and some unique European battles you haven't done before.  The battles on Hill 402 at the bunker are pretty awesome.  I've seldom been as engaged by a WWII shooter as I was killing mortar teams and fighting a mounting Nazi advance, scrounging for ammo during brief lulls.  Well done.

Overall, this game is great.  It's short, so you may wait for it to drop 10 bucks, but the online play more than makes up for the brief nature of the single player.  If you're a WWII shooter fan, this is a must for your collection.  You'll have a good time and enjoy some COD2 mechanics.
summary: Great Shooter, here is the good and the bad

After a long 2 years, EA SPORTS released its first golf title on the next gen consoles.  The newly branded EA SPORTS Rory McIlroy PGA TOUR has been rebuilt from the ground up using the Frostbite engine.  Complete rebuilds are always cause for concern as far as content goes.  With a week gone since launch, lets see how Rory McIlroy PGA Tour shakes out.

One area where this game truly shines is its presentation.  The game uses very authentic presentation styles (The Golf Channel), as well as some great overlays that help tell the story of your round.  The commentary itself is extremely well done.  It flows very well and you even hear a few stutters from the commentators like a real life broadcast.  Transitions in the commentary are seamless between the banter and stroke by stroke action.  There are tines where they will talk about other golfers on the course, past rounds historically, as well as your previous round if you are playing a multiple round tournament.

While the commentary is well done, it is HIGHLY repetitive.  If I hear Frank he had the touch of a plumber on that one again I might vomit.  Honestly I have only heard a variety of maybe 6 different commentary lines when missing a putt.

The other area that really shines is the graphics.  This game really pops throughout the gameplay.  The courses look almost exactly like the real course.

The gameplay itself is very well done, albeit with some questionable design decisions.  If you have played an EA SPORTS Golf title before this, the gameplay should feel very familiar.  The usual up and down swing is back again as is the fade/draw diagonal swing.

The up and down swing on the left analog stick has a back swing accuracy feedback as well as a club speed accuracy feedback on the higher difficulty settings.  The back swing accuracy feedback gives you an over-swing and under-swing modifier broken down by percentage (under-swing 4%) that affects your possible stroke distance.  The club head speed works the same way.

My biggest complaint would be that no matter the difficulty, swinging the golf club is way too forgiving.  The penalty for missing a perfect swing right or left feels non-existent.  Missing a swing forward or back provides a good penalty on the higher swing difficulties and that is fine.  But the ease in hitting the fairways is really holding the gameplay back from the next level.

The player swings look beautiful but in the single player (pro career) there is no way to customize your swing.  To me that is a very odd design decision.

Also on the suspect list is the overall lack of available courses at launch.  Missing are the stalwarts like Pebble Beach and Augusta.  Launching with just 8 courses and 2 fantasy courses is a long way from what we are used to.  Granted they have said that more will be added through the cycle but still frustrating to be repeating the same courses after only a week of play.

The main modes I have played in previous EA SPORTS Golf titles are always the Be a Pro and Online Tournaments.  I love being able to create a crazy looking golfer, build him up, and take him online in tournaments versus my friends.

Sadly you are left with very few choices for your created golfer this year.  All of the choices are very mundane (standard), you have to actually make your character look like a golfer which is fine for some but many like to add some flair to their golfer.  The lack of customization in Be A Pro is near the top of my list for most disappointing aspects of this title.

Another area that isn't up to par in the Be A Pro career mode also deals with missing features.  The lack of a tour calendar this year is highly annoying.  No longer can you look ahead or skip ahead to the tournaments you want to play.

One glaring omission on the links in career mode is that we are still missing a playoff when golfers are tied atop the leaderboard at the end of each tournament.  This is an item I thought they would have in this year for sure.  Playoff situations that can add a ton of fun and pressure are now just a flip of the coin.

Online Play

Not much going on here as you can play head to head online or join weekly/daily tournaments.  The real kicker is that its only stroke-play, no best ball, scrambles, or skins.  The lack of customizable tournaments is a killer as well.  Many of us were expecting to make our own tournaments that we could play amongst friends with our own custom settings.

Thats a tough pill to swallow in the online world.  Also another glaring omission is Country Clubs.  Being able to team with groups of your friends and play the way you want to is crucial to online golf.  It is sorely missed.

Nightclub Challenge

If you have played the EA SPORTS Golf mobile game this is very similar.  Its a linear arcade challenge based mode.  Basically there are several types of challenges including hitting a bullseye style target, breaking glass panes, using a remote-controlled ball through cricket style gates, and many others.

Nightclub Challenge is a different experience that allows for some quick change of pace fun.  Really a decent addition to the game and something that will keep the casual player in the game.

Final Thoughts

While EA SPORTS Rory McIlroy plays a very good game of golf, there really isn't much to it.  Sure we have been told this isn't a yearly title and will be built upon post launch but that doesnt change what we have now.  I will certainly continue to play because the game play itself is VERY good.  But we need some meat and potatoes added to these game modes.  Until then I give it a 6.5/10.
summary: EA SPORTS Rory McIlroy Shoots a Bogey in Round 1

reviewText:
As many other reviewers of this game, I'm a long-time fan of the AC titles and was also disappointed when they decided to drop Sony.  Very few flight games have found their way onto the PS3 and I think that this game missed a golden opportunity to really shine.  As I mentioned in the title, this game is good, but not great.  It may have gotten a few extra bonus points for being the first modern jet game for the PS3, but you'll have to judge for yourself.

The Good - This game has an amazing selection of aircraft, including some pleasant surprises.  The cockpits are all well done from what I've seen (I've used about 20 different aircraft thus far) and the aircraft themselves are also look pretty good.  The missions are slightly more reality based than many in the AC series (real jets, ships, tanks, etc), and is, overall, a lot of fun.  The game is easy to get into with a fairly low learning curve and is quite addicting.  Also, GeoEye did an outstanding job of integrating real imagery, even though it isn't the highest resolution and really starts to pixelate at less than about a thousand feet.

The Bad - For starters, this game is S-H-O-R-T!  With a grand total of 19 missions, none of them lasting more than about 15 minutes, you can easily beat this game 2 or 3 times on a Saturday afternoon.  The experience points process is an interesting approach, which does help with replayability, but I would rather have seen the accumulation of money instead since you are, essentially, a mercenary.  I enjoy unlocking planes and being able to purchase what you want.  As good as the graphics are, they are lacking in a few areas as well.  The aircraft are pretty good, but I don't think they took advantage of what the PS3 is capable of.  The jets in Ace Combat 6 on the Xbox definitely look better, which is sad considering the game is almost a year and a half old.  One thing that especially bugged me was the afterburner flames - they are essentially orange ellipses.  I think a few old PS2 games, including Aero Elite, did a better job of rendering them.  Not just that, but some jets, most notably the A-10 (I haven't used any of the other sub-sonic aircraft) don't even have afterburners, so I found it a little ridiculous.  Also, they got at least one name wrong - the "Mig-25", is actually a Mig-31.  I know this is nit-picky, but come on!  There is also no real sense of speed, which is particularly evident with low-level flying.  The ability to land aircraft would also have been a nice option, but oh well.

In conclusion, when I first started playing this game, I might have even given it five stars.  After 4-5 hours of gameplay it would've dropped to 4.  Now that I've beaten the game and started reflying missions just to accumulate XP, it's dropped to a 3.  I still own Aero Elite and Ace Combat Zero for PS2 and in 6 months will almost certainly prefer playing them to this game.  Ubisoft gets a B for effort and a C for delivery.  Maybe next time...

reviewText: Handsome Jack made these games amazing and it's beautiful on the PS4 and smooth!

I can't think of a worse game since the 1990s. It's terrible. Here's why:

Origin: EA's dream of Steam is a steaming pile of worthlessness. I get weekly updates that "will take just a few minutes", when all I want to do is play this one, single game. So you wait while Origin's Steamwannabe patches or boots up. Then game time? No, of course not! Then your browser, the one with the non-optional plugin you were forced to install, boots up and takes you to the website. In game browser? No, that would not eat up nearly enough resources or be nearly as invasive! So you get in there. Let's say you just want to play the single player game. You've not had to wait for Origin to open and probably patch, then go to the web browser, then you can actually click "single player game" and play the game you have already decided might have been a mistake. Minutes later, you get into the game.

So far I've had floating bodies, and a fallen tree that disappeared as I passed it, only to have an enemy pop out of the now no-longer-there tree and stab me. This after running...running...running...following one of your AI comrades. I fired maybe 10 rounds, and running...following...running...fire 4 rounds, jump down, fire a few more, have the fallen tree disappear and get stabbed. I got half way through and had to stop.

I did give this game an extra star for the "how fun is this" if only because they kept Punkbuster, unlike the COD people, and the multiplayer isn't too bad. But after forced to start Origin (a store front pretending to be DRM), then go to the website (hey look, another storefront!), then into the game...nah, I'll just load up COD4 or Arma2, Far Cry 3...or heck, anything other than this disaster.

After this, and Bad Company 2...well, I'm done. Battlefield 1942 was one of the best ever FPS games. It might as well have been made in 1942 compared to this disaster.
summary: Probably the worst game I've purchased in ten years

Vanquish could have been an epic disaster.  It introduces a gameplay style that has never been done before, and the action is incredibly intense, and nearly non-stop, for the duration of its 8 hour campaign.  But one thing I learned while playing this game, is that when you have the masters of the medium, Platinum Games, behind the helm, you can rest assured that you're going to have a great action experience that is not only expertly crafted, but unlike anything you've ever played before.

Vanquish is a cover-based, sci-fi third person shooter with a major twist...that twist being your ability to travel at incredibly fast speeds from place to place using your suit's boost power.  The game is structured in a way that if you stay in one place for too long, enemies will either flank or destroy your cover, so if you don't keep moving, you won't remain alive for very long.  In addition to the boost, the suit's enhanced reaction abilities allow you to seemingly slow down time in order to get precision shots with your weapons.  Both the boost and slow motion abilities use your suit's cooldown powers, so the entire game is a balancing act of not overheating your suit while causing as much destruction as possible as you move from place to place at a high speed.  Combine this with an outrageous scenario involving evil Russians on a giant space station , along with with a high pace of action that makes a Michael Bay movie look like "The English Patient", and it seems like something like this just wouldn't be able to come together without turning into a huge mess of a video game.  But Vanquish couldn't be further from that.

Vanquish has some of the tightest controls I've played in any video game.  And it is due to these controls that the gameplay is able to come together so well.  Early on in the game, after going through a well made tutorial, you'll be thrust into a battle that will quickly teach you what Vanquish is all about.  You'll likely die more than a few times, but what the game smartly does is it forces you to learn how to properly play the game.  You'll not only learn that taking cover will only protect you for a brief, fleeting moment, but you'll also learn how awesome your suit's powers are.  You'll realize you don't really need the cover system too much, as you quickly learn how to harness your suit's powers bring down mobs of enemy robots in ways that will make you feel incredibly powerful.  Once you get into Vanquish's rhythm, the game is pure joy.  You'll become nearly untouchable. Also, you'll start to notice into the smaller details, like the intriguing story, the very cool, upgradable weapons that become available to you, and the different tactics required to take certain enemies down.  As it all came together for me, I realized that I was playing the most tightly-crafted, well-working shooters I'd ever played.  Not only that, but the game looks fantastic, and has an awesome soundtrack to boot.

Platinum Games, following up on their incredible achievement that is Bayonetta, has really delivered the goods with Vanquish.  It is innovative, action packed, and incredibly fun to play.  Like Bayonetta did with action/beat em up games, Vanquish has really upped the ante in the third person shooter genre, and given it its own unique spin that stands apart from the rest of the pack.  It's a shame that this game didn't catch on more than it did when it released in late 2010, as it's truly an underappreciated gem in the PS3/360 catalogue, but I think time will be kind to this game's legacy.  If you love fast-paced shooters and want to play a truly innovative entry into the genre, don't miss out on Vanquish.  A truly awesome game.
summary: An overlooked and underappreciated gem - one of the finest third person shooters ever made

reviewText: The local game is amazing, great graphics, and the fun fast Street Fighter gameplay that we all love. The problems start when you go online. Unless you're ready to study the millisecond timing of moves, combos, counters, and weaknesses of every player, then don't bother, because there are too many people out there with waaaay too much time on their hands who will kill you every time and suck all of the fun out of the game.
summary: Great game, but multiplayer is annoying

reviewText: MLB 12 the Show has freeze issues. At first I thought it was my Playstation that was causing this, so I went out and bought a brand new system only to find out that the freeze bug exists in the game itself. The game usually freezes (1 in 3 chance) during the sixth or seventh inning when playing Road to the Show mode. Since I have my settings set to "All Pitches," the freeze occurs around an hour or so into gameplay. This doesn't just make this game frustrating..... It makes it unplayable. After discussing this issue with friends of mine who have played previous versions of this game, I found out that this is a reoccurring problem with "The Show" series. Until Sony's San Diego team recognizes and fixes this freeze bug, I will be playing 2K Sports MLB 2K12. Too bad... Sony's MLB 12 The Show really had potential.

reviewText:

Mistaking this for a different type of computer game, I had to ask my son for help with Guild Wars 2, and he was glad to help. I'm sure it was because he is a loving son, and had nothing to do with the fact that he was able to spend hours playing Guild Wars 2 with my blessing. So, my review is from the point of view of someone unfamiliar with MMORPG games. I'll do my best to review it.

First off, the graphics in a game are very important to me and what I saw in Guild Wars 2 was terrific. If the graphics do not wow me, I generally do not like a game. I really like the variety of areas in the world and the amount of detail. And, there's a snowy area- my favorite- as well as areas with interesting vegetation and architecture. Often, I was reminded of the later Myst graphics or even the architecture in Dinotopia. (OK, I'm dating myself here!)

You have several choices of characters to play as, each very different from another and having many options as to looks, as well as what job you hold. I'm coming from the world of adventure games where you are pretty much play as what the game is designed for you to be, so with Guild Wars 2 that's pretty cool. And, with the game changing in response to what you do, that promises for many, many hours of play.

As for playing... Well, I must admit that I cannot do shooters. If it involves more than moving a mouse and clicking (slowly, at that) I'm toast.  So, I had to watch in amazement as my son battled some very nasty looking critters. He said movement and abilities are controlled via the WASD  and keyboard, and the mouse controls attacking and your view, and that movement is typical of MMO games. Further, he commented that an experienced player would have no problem, however anyone new to MMOs (like me) would probably need to read up a bit and watch a few videos to learn about them first.

My attempts at an MMO were short, confusing, and not pretty, but my son assured me that the game's controls were neither clumsy nor difficult to play. I'll have to take his word for it because to me it looked like there was a lot to keep track of, what with skills, attributes, weapons, etc. and a lot going on at once.

I like the fact that once you buy the game, you can play it without forking over money every month just to play a game you've already bought. Seems to me, though, that there should be a way to play the game by yourself, and not have to hook up online with others online.

So, I guess for those who like MMOs, then Guild Wars 2 will be enjoyable and easier on the wallet than some of the other games out there, and it will provide many hours of play in an interesting variety of places. Happy gaming!
summary: Beautiful places to visit, no subscription fee.

reviewText:
In brief: This game is designed to have a certain "play time" it does this with a lot of tedious tasks rather than being fun that whole time.  But it's in an outstanding backdrop, with pretty good voice acting, decent action, and fairly fun all around.
I'm a demanding consumer, and when I fork my cash over I expect a lot in return and Assassin's creed 2 was a bit of a disappointment, less so then Assassin's creed 1 as many of the incredibly tedious jump puzzles can simply be skipped (along with their rewards) if you'd rather avoid them.  And after this I'll be giving up on the franchise.  Jump puzzles and fake chases are deliberately added to waste time, which could be argued is a form of temporary murder. It's not wrong to include them but if the majority of your "game" is a frustrating interface and hobbling you have a design problem. Don't get me wrong, Assassin's creed 2 is an order of magnitude better than any Drake's fortune game in that the illusion of options is generally well maintained and mediocrity is well disguised.  The window dressing does a great job in this case, with very good voice acting, nice cut scenes, interesting stories with contrived plots, cool outfits and weapons (more important than you might think), and an amazing amount of detail in cities (my favorite part).  I actually like to run around the cities because they generally do a great job with it's recreation.  I've been to all the cities in this version of the game and have to say that it's reminiscent enough that it took me back to my own memories of the places especially Florence.  The combat is pretty decent, but honestly it feels a lot like button mashing a lot of the time (Square, square, R1+square, square, square, square . . .) and the experience is greatly improved by the animations and kill shots for me which I just love.  Assassinations are always fun too as the player can generally choose to plan them out or run in guns blazing if that's your style.  But transparently contrived sequences will always annoy me.  In Pac man I know I'm limited to the predefined grid so it never surprises me to be confined to it throughout the game, but I'd be very pissed if on level 20 a wall appeared right in front of a powerball I was about to grab.  In Assassin's Creed 2 there are frequently times when you realize that throwing daggers would be perfect for this situation, but they're grayed out JUST for this sequence because the developers don't want you to use them just here where they'd be perfect.  Find yourself surrounded by enemies?  Smoke bombs are grayed out on this mission.  Other than using throwing daggers on thieves and archers, I was never able to use them as described.  Never used Smoke bombs either, the one time I felt I needed them they had no effect.  I ended up with a lot of unused supplies.  Then there are the chase scenes where the guy is WAITING for you to chase him, or where he suddenly gets a 200' lead for unknown reasons, or how you can fail a tail because you're waiting a head of where you think he'll be (first run through) rather then where he's waiting for you to be.  And on and on.  If the hidden blade can always give a fatal counter attack, but they can miraculously avoid the counters from more practical fighting weapons, why ever use the real weapons? Why can't I keep the rapier I picked up from a guard and use it permanently, must I really buy an identical weapon myself? Why are there wanted posters in places where only the wanted can reach them?  And lets not forget the jump puzzles, the kind where you have to make 3+ jumps of varied complexity exactly correctly and sequentially or restart the whole processes which takes 5 to 10 minutes.  Or Accidently fall and not die and be forced to go back to the point before all your check points with no other way to kill yourself or load the last check point(a process that should take zero seconds).  A lot of this can be ignored, forgotten, or given a pass because the genre pulls this crap all the time, but I expect more from my video games.  If you like all that BS, more power to you enjoy the game, but games don't have to be like that and I don't think they should be.  Assassin's Creed 2 is not amazing, but it is a solid game.  The pickpocket was an inspired idea, I hate those guys so much I would go out of my way to kill them (well done on that developers!).  The addition of hirelings was also a nice touch, so when you're sick of counters not working as you expect you can just hire some thugs to distract the opposition while you continue with what needs to be done.  The villa aspect was interesting as well, but felt poorly developed.  I understand that having a lot of money can be "game breaking" but it's my game let me break it if I want to. Other slight faults include shops that automatically replace your current load out while the game encourages collecting, and in this way collecting inhibits game playing.  A lot of these observations and demands for improvement come from having played a lot of video games but now finding less time for them raising the bar of "worth playing".  The rest of it is from playing games from Bethesda game studios (not the softworks), and seeing games from 2009 continue to fail to meet a bar that was 2006.
summary: Adventure gaming isn't what it used to be.

reviewText: 2 months and the battery has gone bad.  No replacements available either!  What a bad experience.  Like others I saw "Energizer" and assumed it would work fine.  Didn't do my homework.  Now I'm stuck with this bad product.

I am not new to the MMORPG scene. I've most recently played World of Warcraft and Guild Wars; I was looking for a similar experience in a more D&D-based world. I hoped DDO would be the game for me--a MMO-version of Neverwinter Nights. It wasn't.

Everything about this game is substandard and disappointing. The graphics are very dated and the animation isn't terribly smooth. Beyond the first few quests, there is no possible way to solo. Characters only get XP from completing quests...as boring and repetitive as they are. Monsters rarely ever drop items. The game does not explain the skills or spells well at all (and this coming from someone not alien to the DnD world).

In addition to all this, I have problems staying connected to the server. It seems like every 15 minutes I get disconnected, and this is something I don't experience in any other MMORPG I play. The technical support/customer service is especially poor as well.

I truly feel like this game was a waste of money. I urge anyone considering this game to try it before purchasing it. In the meantime, I will wait for Neverwinter Nights 2 since the original was the best D&D-like RPG I've ever played.

reviewText:
Maybe your not John travolta in saturday night fever, but we all like to get down and boogie-oogie-oogie every once in a while.  And with DDR Max, now you can in the comfort of your very own living room.  Lord knows in these days of McDonalds, its a wonderfull day indeed when you can play a video game, and lose weight.  DDR Max does away with the dancing characters, and puts in a new twist, Music videos.  The music has also greatly improved in this version (as opposed to Konamix) and in my opinion, the game itself is much more challenging.  There are 4 modes of difficulty, Light; Standard; Heavy and the "secret" mode (I call it secret because I had no freakin' idea it was there, and found it accidently) Challenging mode, wich is flippin' hard.
One of the many great things about DDR is its more like playing an instrument, than playing a video game, its not really something you get tired of all too quickly, so paying 60 bucks for the game and pad isn't really that bad, if only because the games replay value is so high.
There really isn't any better feeling than beating a super-hard-psychotic song in this game, especially when there are witnesses all around.  And I think there is something to be said for the fact that this game is amazing for parties, and get-togethers.  Now, granted, its not the best thing videogame wise, and every new release isn't much more than a ton of new songs, but thats all part of the fun.  My only complaint with the regular dance pads is that the bunch up under feet sometimes, and that gets really annoying, but there is a platform you can buy if you don't mind sinking the 70 bucks in to get it.  I eventually adjusted, but sometimes, the vinyl pads can wear-out, hasn't happened to me yet, but its something to think about.
Pros:
Good rewards for defeating songs
Lots of fun for versus
Keeps on challenging you, completing the entire game inside out should keep you busy for at least a year, if not more.
Cons:
Pads bunch up
Music gets a little old, but thats just because its music, and thats what music does.

reviewText:
Banjo-Kazooie: Nuts & Bolts is a great game for families and gamers alike.  In a word, its just plain fun.  There's nothing too deep here in the way of story or character elements.  Its more about having fun in many different types of challenges and game worlds, with an emphasis on building your own vehicles in order to conquer your current challenge or objective.  Add to that some excellent bright and colorful graphics, and you have a great game overall.

Pros: Game is just FUN -- Creating your own vehicles is a blast and gives the user unlimited possibilities -- Still a decent amount of old fashioned platforming -- Great graphics -- Retains alot of the loveable traits of the old banjo games

Cons: Creating vehicles, while the interface is easy, could be pretty daunting for young kids -- If you get frustrated easily with losing and retrying challenges, you might want to steer clear -- The game overall is a tad difficult, which again could turn younger gamers off

Overall I'd definitely recommend this game to people of all ages, but I'd advise to be careful with younger children as they might find the gameplay and vehicle creator difficult.  Luckily, if you are devoid of imagination or just lazy, the game throws a multitude of custom built vehicles at your that will serve just fine in all of the challenges.  Add to this that the game is cheaper than most, and its a must buy!

Edit (6 July 2013): I'm putting this from a 2 star rating to a 3 star rating.

It really has held up well and has protected my Vita. It's quite impressive actually. But I can't stand how the upper flap is layered still; it's still unusable.

----------
Original review:

Generally, it does what it says. It carries the PSVita and protects it from harm. I've dropped it once on concrete on accident and nothing was harmed. It gets the job done.

However, I'm not happy with [mostly] everything else. The carabiner that was suppose to come with it, didn't even fit in the small loop. I've tried shoving it in, but nope. Doesn't fit at all (so I left it in the box). The top "level" where all the games and memory cards, etc go is tucked into the case in such a way that it always flaps into the top. Some pockets for the memory cards are sown into mesh. This makes no sense whatsoever. They could have put a zipper instead of open pockets so that the games,etc won't fall out. I also would NOT recommend putting earphones in it. There is just not enough space because of the flapping "layer."

When the Vita is in the case and strapped in, you can't push the L or R buttons. I really wish it did so I could at least play on it while it's in the case.

On the center that holds the top and bottom together, I can see some parts already being undone. I've had it... almost 3 weeks now?

For the price of it right now, ~$8-ish, it's decent. It does it's job. If you have a few extra dollars to spend, I'd probably get a better one.

The case I received didn't have that dreaded smell, so that's a good thing.

Edit (5 Feb. 2013): I'm lowering this to 2 stars because I suspect that it's scratching my PSVita's screen. About a week into use, I noticed 3 0.5-1 inch long cuts on my screen (luckily I had a screen protector) and it had to have come from the case. If they got rid of that layer on top, I think it would have been fine.

Edit (19 Mar. 2013): I'm actually surprised that this case has held up for so long. There hasn't been any major rips or tears or anything like that. As for the case being too small to hold the Vita, I made a quick adjustment that seems to have done the trick. Instead of putting the Vita inside (the right way up), I put it in upside down so that it sits on the top flap. This method stops the two "joysticks" from being smashed since the system is being held up by the two cords when the case is closed.
summary: I'm not impressed, but I'm not too dissatisfied.

reviewText: Are you the kind of person that can't listen to a Broadway soundtrack without tapping your foot and bopping out in your chair? Do you want to get some exercise without even realizing you're working? If you're anything like me, I think you'll like this game. Remember the dancers in the Broadway hit, "Fame", dancing their hearts out to that great song? Or the dancers in "All That Jazz" doing that cool tap dancey thing? Well, this isn't quite as complicated as all that but its lots of movement and fairly easy choreography that you follow along with while the Wiimote records your moves. You can play with up to four people. You choose one of four characters that you would like to be at the beginning, when you choose the song. There are 20 songs, some of which are: * "All That Jazz" * "Aquarius" * Caberet * Luck Be a Lady * Lullaby of Broadway * "Bend and Snap" * "One Night Only" * "Dreamgirls" * "Time Warp" * "Fame" * "We're in the Money" * "Let The Sunshine In" * "You Can't Stop the Beat" * "Little Shop of Horrors Theme" * My Favorite Things * And there's more.... The idea of the game is to follow your chosen dancer, like in a mirror image, with dance, rhythm and arm movements. One of the options is to set it so you see the words to the songs at the top of the screen and they're highlighted, kind of like a bouncing ball but without the ball, so you can sing along. There really isn't any recording of your voice so it's just kind of for your own amusement. When choosing a song, you see a difficulty level and an effort level shown by the number of stars. Several of the songs are at a somewhat slow pace so it's pretty easy to follow along. There are some little icon figures that move along the bottom that show upcoming moves. I found it easier just to watch the dancers. The game does a reasonably good job of recording your movements and you can see with a gauge above your dancer whether you've missed the move "X", got an "OK" or a "Great". It's possible to get combo points by scoring several "Greats" in a row. Your points are totaled up at the end in each category. Ok, so why did I give this game only 4 stars if I like it so much? Well, I just got the game today and after playing it for a couple hours I'm already scoring pretty well. It's not that I'm really good at this sort of thing, in fact I'd have to say I'm pretty uncoordinated most of the time. It's just that I like games that are more challenging and I want to get a lot of hours of enjoyment out of it. Now I do have to say that I really, REALLY had fun playing with it tonight. I love the music, the graphics are pretty good and I just like the whole idea of the game. But I'm not sure a couple of weeks from now that I'll be challenged enough to be looking forward to playing it as much. I always compare this type of game to We Cheer and We Cheer 2, by Namco. Those are rhythm games as well, kind of on the same principle, but I couldn't even get past the first song for over a week. I played those games for hours and hours trying to open new levels of songs and stages. (I still have fun playing them). With Dance on Broadway, there are 20 songs and as far as I can tell, everything is accessible right away, no additional challenges or hidden things to open. Some of the songs like All That Jazz and Aquarius are very easy to score on because of the way these games record the Wii movements. Now, if you want to follow along with the steps and really look like the dancers on the screen it will be more difficult. But this game, like others of it's type records only your arm movements to score. So would I buy the game again? Yeah, I love the music and I'm a sucker for rhythm and musical type games. But I wish it had more levels and was more challenging. The challenge for me will be not so much the scoring, which I think I'll probably be able to ace in a fairly short time, but trying to really copy all the footwork and look like the dancers onscreen. And while it's not as energetic as some games like We Cheer, my arms are sore after playing it for a while. I'm not exactly huffing and puffing but it's still good exercise. I just wish Ubisoft would have added a little more interest and more levels to this game. It's good as far as it goes but seems as though it was rushed to market too soon. Update 6/27/10 - After playing with this game for 10 days I'm finding that the motion sensing is sometimes a little quirky. It doesn't always pick up the motions of the Wiimote as quickly as it should. But we've also had some really big fun with this game when we had friends over. After a couple glasses of wine we started up the game, and after watching, had 4 people playing at a time and it was hilarious! Watching a line of "dancers" make their Broadway debut with exaggerated dance movements and expressions was way funny. And trying to outdo each other on the points kept everyone playing for a long time. Because there are a lot of easy dance numbers like the one from "Hair" or "All That Jazz" everyone can score reasonably well after just a few tries. And there are definitely some that are more difficult and energetic. So I have to give the "party potential" 5 stars even though I rated the game 4 stars for the rest.
summary: Get up off the couch and make your Broadway debut!

reviewText: Great game, I play it with my daughter fun family game,  she loves to customize the characters

Similar in scope to Call of Duty.  Some of the scenarios require problem solving skills to defeat the foes.  For the most part, this is a rock em sock em kick ass game that will get your heart beat up and challenge your trigger finger.  I like it enough to pre-order KILLZONE 3.

I played this game about 9 months ago (January 2005) and quite frankly, it was a great First Person Shooter in my opinion. Now I've played a ton of FPS games in the past, and I'll be honest - this game isn't as good as the Half-Life Series. That's just one of the greatest FPS Sagas ever conceived I'm afraid. But nonetheless, "Doom 3" is fantastic and is sure to scare even the hardiest and merciless FPS Veterans. On to the review...

Mars. The 22nd Century. You play a Marine brought in to assist in security operations on a Top-Secret Research Facility on the Red planet. However, when you land you are warned to leave the planet immediately by a seemingly paranoid scientist. Ignoring this, you continue on your path and get straight to work. You are subsequently given your first assignment to find a missing scientist - and upon finding him, all hell breaks loose. You are then flung into a world of hideous monstrousities, demons and darkness as you fend for your very life in the besieged facility. The storyline borrows from the older "Doom" games and evidently also "Half-Life." The storyline's a bit formulaic, but it's good enough for me: hey, it's an FPS, not a Strategy or Role-playing game! So "Doom 3" gets 7/10 for its storyline.

The gameplay is great, there's no doubt about that. You'll constantly find yourself interpolating between your weapons arsenal and flashlight as you navigate the dark and ominous corridors of the UAC Facility. It's a far more realistic approach to combat, though you'd think that your armour would have a built-in flashlight. Still, it makes for some terrifying combat and scary-ass conflict. The guns range from small to f****** big, so you get your standard loadout as such. And you can carry every single gun too, which is impossible, but fantastic! The gameplay is fast and horrifying, and you'll constantly find yourself backing up and firing at hulking figures and at times running the hell away from some enemies. I reckon the gameplay's flawless and so it gets 10/10 in my book.

The Graphics are stunning, or so I think so. The ambient lighting is fantastic, the details on the environments, characters and weapons are fabulous and the effects are simply jaw-dropping. And the game's supposed to be dark and foreboding, and the environments are a reflection of the games' atmosphere. There are blood-stains on the walls, totally dark areas, dimly-lit corridors, a hazardous and toxic planet surface and eventually you even go to hell! Woohoo! Now THAT'S entertainment! 10/10 for the graphics.

Now how's about a look at your weapons eh? Basically your weapons range from your fists and a standard issue 9mm Pistol to firearms like the mighty plasma gun and devastating BFG (which can fire individual blasts of plasma or one charged ball of furious death at your enemies.) It's all alot of fun to sucker punch zombies using your fists (I live for punching zombies!) and if one pi$$es you off, just hit him with a flashlight. Maybe that's not your game, but messing with the undead is just heaven (ironically). There are plenty of weapons to keep you happy and even an artifact that's great for not only killing enemies, but restoring your health too. Once again "Doom 3" gets 10/10 for weapons.

Now for the enemies. Basically they range from your common garden-variety zombie (both thin and fat-a$$ed) to your almighty Hell-Knight and Arch-Vile. Zombies are easy to kill and the most fun to destroy. Then Imps are evil looking creatures that throw fireballs at you and also have a nasty claw attack - may I suggest a Shotgun for killing these guys? My personal method is to walk right up to them and blow a hole in their face. It's a very effective attack. Then you get these flying disembodied heads called Lost Souls. They are excruciatingly annoying, especially in groups. Use a pistol for 3 and under, and a machine-gun for any more than that. Then Cacodemons (that look simliar to those Octopuses in "Duke Nukem 3D.") Float around and fire plasma blasts from their mouths. Suggested weapons: machine-gun for 2 and under, and either a chain-gun or plasma gun for more than that. Then you get these Double-Headed Demons called Maggots - they're incredibly weak and usually 1 or 2 shotgun blasts send them back to hell. Then there are these Spider-Creatures (called Wraiths) that can appear and re-appear. They're also terribly weak. Wait for one to get next to you, and as he lifts his mandible, blow his head off with a shotgun shell. Then you get these small-spider things (both adult and juvenile, the former known as Trites and the latter as Ticks) - use a machine-gun or pistol on them - they're weak but DEADLY in groups. Then there are Cherubs that are also weak but highly aggressive. I prefer a shotgun for a couple of them but any other automatic weapon is preferable for more. Use your discretion. There are also Possessed Marines that use everything from pistols to shotguns to machine-guns. I like to use equal force on one enemy, but a plamsa gun or chain-gun is ideal for more than that. Commando Demons are soldiers who have been taken over and mutated by Doctor Malcolm Betruger. Some will run at you and use a tentalce attack on you, others fire chain-guns. They're dumb and aggressive, much like the Jocks at you high school. I suggest a Chain Gun or Plasma Gun on these guys. Revenants are skeletal in nature and fire shoulder mounted rockets at you. I say Plasma Gun first and in open areas (such as the planet surface) use a Rocket Launcher. Pinky Demons are quadrupedal and are relatively weak. Shotgun all the way I say. Mancubus' are fat and grotesque and fire massive plasma blasts from two huge cannons. They're basically immobile - use any big gun, including the BFG on these guys. And if possible, just run away. Hell Knights are the big Kahunas in "Doom 3." Like Imps, they throw plasma balls - just alot bigger. And don't get close, because you will be battered, bitten and smashed to pieces by these lumbering behemoths. The weapon choice is easy - the bigger the gun, the better! Arch Viles cast spells to summon other demons and also create trails of fire which absolutely destroy you. Kill these guys first! Use a Plasma Gun or Rocket Launcher on them. Those are your basic enemies, but you'll face bosses like The Vagary (which comes back later on in the game as a common enemy), The Sabaoth, The Guardian and the Absolutely massive and awe-inspiring Cyberdemon. The enemies are so diverse and numerous that "Doom 3" deserves 11/10 in my book!

In terms of difficulty, "Doom 3" can be pretty tough in some places. But Veteran is passable and Nightmare can be completed (ask me, I did it!). I suggest that veterans of FPS games play on the Veteran setting and then the Nightmare setting, and newbies should play the Marine setting. "Doom 3" gets 10/10 for difficulty on the Nightmare setting, 8/10 on Veteran, 6/10 for Marine and 5/10 for Trainee. "Doom 3" also gets 7/10 for lastability (without Multiplayer capabilities) and 9/10 for consumers with access to High Speed Internet connections and LAN Networks.

Overall "Doom 3" scores a solid gold 92%. It's dark and foreboding, action-packed, riddled with blood thirsty enemies and bosses and possesses all the necessary components for an FPS classic! It's not the greatest FPS I've ever played and not the scariest game either, but "Doom 3" has a fine balance of both crucial elements. So I would definitely recommend it to all serious FPS players, but there again, there are some fans who apparently haven't enjoyed "Doom 3." But that aside, I certainly enjoyed it and the Expansion Pack, although short, was alot of fun. So go on, buy it, borrow it or steal it today, but at least give it a decent chance before you judge it. Peace!
summary: DOOM 3 - A first-person shooter worth much acclaim...

reviewText: Tomb raider is always good. Reminds of playing zelda on my old Nintendo, always challenging puzzles and boss battles!

For years, many niche genre's were being suppressed by the flood of first person shooters that dominated last generation. Survival horror attempted to adapt, by shifting the focus away from horror, and closer to something resembling Call of Duty or Gears of War. Recent installments of Resident Evil and Dead Space serve as prime examples, of compromised integrity and identity, in the interest of attaining mass appeal.

Some quick background on me:

Survival horror is my favorite genre. I am in my 30's, and have very fond memories of playing Resident Evil, Silent Hill, Fatal Frame (etc) during my high school years. Watching the genre slowly erode, and fade away, was very disheartening. There were only a handful of legitimate horror games last generation (Siren: Blood Curse being my favorite). Most were just gory action fests.
However, the genre has been going through a resurgence, through the independent scene on PC in recent years. I had my fingers crossed that this would spill over onto consoles, and it finally has...

The Evil Within

When Shinji Mikami announced his intentions to return to survival horror, the genre that he helped define nearly 15 years ago, I was beyond thrilled. Finally, gaming could be rescued from first person shooter hell, and maybe we could have some diversity again. After anticipating The Evil Within for years, it has finally arrived, and here is my review...

As I reflect on my experience with the game, the most commendable aspect would have to be it's pacing. It really does a masterful job of balancing tension building, resource management, and action. The most obvious comparison is Resident Evil 4, and rightfully so. They share so many characteristics, especially as it relates to gameplay mechanics and environmental design.
Although, I do feel that The Evil Within is more concerned with maintaining it's horror sensibilities, and remaining firmly grounded in that genre. I love Resident Evil 4, but that game really pioneered this shift away from slower paced, methodical survival horror, and established a sub-genre that has become action horror.

Now, I want to be very clear that The Evil Within is not a return to traditional survival horror. I see it more as a blending of traditional, and modern action horror. But, it does retain enough classic elements, to where I feel comfortable using the survival horror label when describing The Evil Within. Slower paced, atmospheric areas are prevalent throughout the experience. The emphasis of resource management, and strategically dispatching enemies are essential to survival. The modern influences stem from a forgiving checkpoint system, and increased action segments in certain areas.

You play as Detective Sebastian Castellanos, responding to a call involving the primary location of the game, Beacon Mental Hospital. As you arrive with your partners by your side, you quickly realize that something has gone terribly wrong. And it is up to you to unravel the truth...

I want to avoid spoilers, so I will try to talk around the key plot points of the story, so I can illustrate some of the issues I had with it. First of which, there really wasn't much of a detailed story presence until the tail end of chapter 8. The first half of the game is very ambiguous, and I had no apparent motivation for progressing through the game, from a story perspective. Perhaps this was done to perpetuate feelings of confusion and uneasiness, but I often felt frustrated by it. Also, the main character Detective Castellanos is underdeveloped, and quite dull. There is some meaningful character development through documents you collect. But nothing from in game action, or dialog. The story is slow out of the gate, but does pick up steam a little past the halfway point. Ruvik is the antagonist, and has an interesting backstory. In fact, he is the most compelling character in the game, by far. The villain really steals the show here, and is quite menacing.

The gameplay feels like an enhanced template from RE4. The combat is visceral and exciting. Shooting ghouls in the leg, and burning them with matches once they hit the ground is very satisfying. There is a nice variety of weapons, and they are all fully upgradable, along with Sebastian's core abilities. This can be done with green brain gel, that you collect throughout the game. You cannot do this at your leisure though, as it can only be done in your hub area. You can travel there through select mirrors in any given level. When in your hub, you can save game progress, use keys to unlock items, or handle upgrades. I really enjoyed this aspect of the game.

The atmosphere can be very oppressing, especially when the psychological horror elements come into play. Shinji Mikami seems to enjoy toying with your sense of reality, and gradually building that sense of tension. I really appreciate horror games that understand the importance of mood and atmosphere, and knowing when to build the tension, then slowly pull back, and give the player some breathing room, only to pull the rug out from underneath them lol. The Evil Within is expertly paced, and the feeling of dread is always looming. I like that it isn't always trying to be "scary", because that is impossible to sustain through long durations. Players will adjust, and become numb to it. The most effective horror games succeed with proper pacing, and The Evil Within is triumphant in this regard.

Is the game scary?? This question has been tossed around quite a bit. Some say yes, while others say no. Which only serves to re-enforce my opinion... that this is all very subjective, and will depend on the individual. If you think it's a scary game, then you are not wrong in thinking so. If you don't, then you are not wrong either. What one person may find scary, another may not. I personally felt tense and uneasy throughout most of my playthrough, with genuine moments of feeling scared periodically.

PROS:

+ Delivering an experience that is representative of the genre. From mood and atmosphere, to resource management and methodical pacing. The Evil Within is a success.

+ Chilling enemy design all around. Laura was especially disturbing, and Boxhead is the stuff of nightmares lol.

+ Combat and weapon variety felt great. I like that stealth is also an option, much of the time. The progression system was implemented very well. This was just a fun game to play.

+ Sound design is top notch. It really added to the immersive qualities of the game.

+ A ton of environmental variety. At times, it may seem a bit jarring, but it does makes sense in the greater
context of the story. I really enjoyed it.

+ A lengthy campaign. My playthrough clocked in at over 24 hours. Though I take my time with games, and tend
to savor every little detail. Those looking to plow through the game, could probably do so in 13-15 hours.

+ New game plus option, with new weapons.

+ The Agony Crossbow is a beast of a weapon. With many different bolt types, that can be upgraded.

+ While the graphics are lacking, the general art design is phenomenal. From environments and character designs,
the amount of detail is impressive.

CONS:

- Many take exception to the mandatory letter boxing display. I also could have lived without this, as it
did obstruct my field of view.

- The story takes too long to get going, and I didn't care for the sequel bait ending. Also, your main
character is a bit of a bore.

- The final boss fight with Ruvik is absurd lol.

- I did notice frequent texture pop-in during cutscenes, and when environments were loading in. Most of the time, this
was rather minor. But on occasion, it was a little disorientating and obtrusive.

- The game does slightly disappoint visually, as the graphics seem high end PS3 caliber. This is a
cross-gen game though. People expecting next-gen graphics had unrealistic expectations, in my opinion.

- The puzzles require little to no thought. It made me wonder why they bothered including them at all, if there
was no intention to challenge the player.

- Those wishing for a return to traditional survival horror, may be disappointed. This is more of a hybrid
of traditional and action horror.

In Closing:

The Evil Within is at the top of this new horror movement. If you are a fan of the genre, and have felt largely ignored by developers, whom have been favoring the 12 year old Call of Duty fanbase for years, then this is your time to rejoice. The landscape is finally changing, as there are many horror games on the horizon in 2015. It's a great time to be a horror fan.

Purchase The Evil Within without hesitation

9/10
summary: Survival Horror Is Back From The Dead
